Graphical abstract A single-site iron- and nitrogen-codoped graphene catalyst shows excellent OER and ORR performance with an overpotential of 275 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a half-wave potential of 0.90 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KOH solution, respectively. Development of high-efficiency atomic transition metal catalysts for oxygen electrode reactions is attractive for regenerative energy conversion and storage technologies. Here we report a facile approach to fabricate an atomic iron- and nitrogen-codoped graphene catalyst with high content of iron (up to 1.5 wt%). The atomic iron-based catalyst on glassy carbon electrodes displays low overpotential (194 mV and 275 mV) reported at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and 0.1 M KOH solutions for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), respectively. In addition, the atomic iron-based composite electrocatalyst exhibits a high half-wave potential of 0.90 V vs. RHE for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in 0.1 M KOH, and a combined ORR and OER potential gap of 0.605 V. Structural characterization and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the efficient active sites for OER and ORR should be FeN4-moiety embedded into the graphene, on which the overpotential-determining step is the OO coupling step. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction Single-site catalysis FeN4-moiety Density-functional theory 1 Introduction Oxygen electrode reactions include oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which are pivotal processes for energy conversion and storage technologies with respect to metal–air batteries, regenerative fuel cells, and electrolyzers [1–4]. Due to the sluggish kinetics of the four-electron transfer oxygen electrode reactions, a large overpotential is required, which usually leads to low efficiency of energy utilization. Although platinum and ruthenium or iridium oxides are active for ORR and OER, respectively, the limited resource, high expense, and poor stability hinder their large-scale applications [5,6]. Besides, these precious metal catalysts are unsuitable for bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalysis [7]. Therefore, increasing effort has been devoted to seeking bifunctional nonprecious metal electrocatalysts with high electrocatalytic performance for both ORR and OER in recent years [8,9]. Although OER/ORR is a reverse reaction couple and shares the same free energy diagram, the practical free energy difference on the same electrocatalyst for OER and ORR might be very tremendous, which results in a good OER/ORR catalyst exhibiting poor catalytic activity towards the reverse reaction [10]. Accordingly, development of bifunctional ORR and OER electrocatalysts with high-performance active sites is still challenging. Some transition-metal oxides/hydroxides [11–14], perovskites [15], sulfides [16], nitrides [17], and selenides [18], and metal-free carbon materials [19] show good OER activity, while some metal (e.g. Fe, Co) and nitrogen codoped materials can efficiently catalyze ORR in alkaline media [20]. The transition metals supported by N-doped carbon materials possess OER and ORR active sites, which show bifunctional catalytic activity due to synergistic mechanisms [21]. However, since the bifunctional materials were usually fabricated by high temperature decomposition of metal–organic frameworks or M−N−C (M = Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni) containing precursors [22,23], sintering and aggregation of metal-based species happened during the pyrolysis processes and it is very hard to obtain a material with uniformly distributed active sites [24]. In addition, although this kind of bifunctional catalysts can catalyze OER and ORR, the active sites for the two reactions are not the same one, which brings great difficulties for reaction mechanism research. Although it has been well-known that Fe- and N-codoped carbon materials show analogous ORR activity to that of Pt/C [25–28], they do not show efficient oxygen evolution catalysis [29,30]. However, some Fe- and N-containing complexes demonstrate excellent chemical or electrochemical water oxidation performance. For example, FeIII-TAMLs can catalyze water oxidation with turnover frequency (TOF) of over 1.3 s−1 using ceric ammonium nitrate as the oxidant [31]. Water oxidation occurs on a monomeric amidate-ligated Fe(III)– aqua complex [FeIII(dpaq)(H2O)]2+ by a single-site mechanism [32]. A pentanuclear iron complex ([FeII 4FeIII(μ3-O)(μ-L)6]3+) can electrochemically catalyze water oxidation with a TOF of 1900 s−1 [33]. Iron is generally regarded as the active site in the most active cobalt-iron (oxy)hydroxide [34] and nickel-iron oxyhydroxide [35] electrocatalysts for OER, since density-functional theory with Hubbard U (DFT + U) calculations revealed low overpotentials at Fe sites. Although the pure iron (oxy)hydroxides display inferior OER activity due to their poor electrical conductivity [34], the electrocatalytic performance can be significantly improved by enhancing their conductivity or modulating the electronic structure of Fe sites [33]. It was reported that amorphous FeOx nanoparticles showed water oxidation with TOF of 9.3 s−1 in the photocatalytic Ru(bpy)3 2+-S2O8 2− system [36]. Therefore, it is a logical approach employing coordination strategy to adjust the electronic configuration of Fe sites to develop efficient bifunctional oxygen electrode catalysts for both ORR and OER. Atomically dispersed catalysts can be obtained by wet chemical reduction procedure [37], one-pot pyrolysis method, pyrolysis–leaching method [30,38], pyrolysis–evaporation strategy [39], or polymerization–pyrolysis–evaporation strategy [40]. Although relatively high metal loadings can be achieved by pyrolysis–evaporation and polymerization–pyrolysis–evaporation strategies, the introduction of volatile zinc salt precursors might lead to residual of zinc, which itself shows excellent ORR performance [41]. One-pot pyrolysis method does not involve second metal ions, which can insure relatively pure metal active sites in the obtained materials, providing better investigation of the reaction mechanism. However, aggregation of metal species often occurred by direct pyrolysis procedure. To address this issue, supports with high surface area and ample oxygen containing functional groups (e.g. graphene oxide) are preferentially considered to coordinate, immobilize, and highly disperse the metal ions. Herein, we adopt a one-pot pyrolysis method to fabricate single Fe sites implanted into nitrogen doped graphene. The Fe@NG-750 sample not only shows excellent ORR activity, but also displays superior OER catalysis with overpotential of only 194 and 275 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and 0.1 M KOH solutions, respectively. The DFT + U results reveal that the active site should be FeN4-site embedded into graphene and the potential determining step for both OER and ORR is the OOH* formation due to the lack of enough stabilization on the FeN4-site. 2 Results and discussion The Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were synthesized by annealing FeCl3/GO precursors under an Ar or NH3 atmosphere at 750 °C for 2 h, respectively. Without nitrogen-doping, besides atomically dispersed Fe, Fe/FeOx nanoparticles can be found in the HRTEM images (Fig. S1), HR-STEM image and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) of Fe@G (Fig. S2). However, for the N-doped sample Fe@NG-750, Fe/FeOx nanoparticles can no longer be observed in the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image (Fig. 1 a), and the high resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (HR-STEM) image (Fig. 1b). In addition, no obvious peaks due to Fe/FeOx nanoparticles can be found in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Fig. S3) and Raman spectra (Fig. S4) of the obtained Fe@NG-750 catalyst, even with the loading content of Fe as high as 1.5 wt% as analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). EDS analysis in a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) reveals that Fe is uniformly dispersed in Fe@NG-750 (Fig. 1c). The atomically dispersed Fe in Fe@NG-750 can be clearly observed by aberration corrected STEM performed in high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) mode (Fig. 1d). These results suggest that N-doping can improve the dispersion of iron ions due to the strong coordination. The BET specific surface area (395 m2/g) of Fe@NG-750 is slightly higher than that (307 m2/g) of Fe@G-750. The higher BET specific surface area of Fe@NG-750 might be due to the leaching of carbons in the nitriding process, which leads to formation of some defects and micropore as depicted in Fig. 1d. The elemental composition and chemical valence state of Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 2 a, the XPS survey spectra display the presence of C (91.29 mol.%), O (8.21 mol.%), and Fe (0.50 mol.%) in Fe@G-750, and C (87.85 mol.%), N (6.94 mol.%), O (4.50 mol.%), and Fe (0.71 mol.%) in Fe@NG-750 (Table S1). The high-resolution C1s spectrum of Fe@NG-750 (Fig. S5) can be deconvolved into three peaks located at ca. 284.66, 285.5, and 286.5 eV, ascribed to the CC, CN, and CO bonds, respectively, while the high-resolution C1s spectrum of Fe@G can be fitted into three peaks located at ca. 284.66, 286.5, and 289.0 eV, related to the CC, CO, and O = CO bonds, respectively [42,43]. The peak positions of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 are located at 710.8 and 724.0 eV, respectively, along with two satellite peaks centered at 715.0 and 729.5 eV (Fig. 2b), verifying that iron species in Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 are mainly Fe2+ [44,45]. Additionally, the N1s XPS peak of Fe@NG-750 can be resolved into five peaks centered at ca. 398.3, 399.3, 400.5, 401.3, and 402.6 eV (Fig. 2c), ascribed to the pyridinic–N, Fe–N, pyrrolic–N, graphitic–N, and oxidized–N, respectively [44–46]. The existence of Fe-N bonds in Fe@NG-750 can be further characterized by the Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum. As depicted in Fig. 2d, a significant peak centered at ca. 1214 cm−1 is observed in the FT-IR spectrum of Fe@NG-750, which is absent for G, NG, and Fe@G-750, indicating that this peak should be ascribed to FeN bonds. In addition, for Fe@G-750, two peaks at 602 and 475 cm−1 can be found, which are attributed to FeO bonds, suggesting that the Fe ions in Fe@G-750 should be coordinated with O atoms. The electrochemical ORR activities of Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were evaluated in 0.1 M KOH. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were first conducted for the Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 catalysts as well as graphene (G) and N-doped graphene (NG) in Ar- and O2-saturated alkaline electrolytes (Fig. S6). As presented in Fig. 3 a, all the graphene-based electrodes do not show obvious cathodic peak in the Ar-saturated solution, whereas they show a well-defined cathodic ORR peak at potentials between 0.70 and 0.90 V vs. RHE in the O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution, suggesting that all show ORR activity. However, the Fe- and N-codoped graphene electrode shows more positive ORR peak potential than graphene, N-doped graphene, and Fe-doped graphene, suggesting the higher ORR activity. From Fig. 3b, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves also show that the Fe@NG-750 display better ORR performance with more positive onset overpotential (Eonset) of 1.03 V, half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.90 V vs RHE and higher diffusion limited current density (J d) of 5.6 mA cm−2 than the other three catalysts (G: Eonset = 0.81 V, E1/2 = 0.65 V, J d = 2.5 mA cm−2; NG: Eonset = 0.82 V, E1/2 = 0.71 V, J d = 3.1 mA cm−2; Fe@G-750: Eonset = 0.84 V, E1/2 = 0.75 V, J d = 3.9 mA cm−2), and even much better than that of the commercial Pt/C (Eonset = 0.94 V, E1/2 = 0.84 V, J d = 5.6 mA cm−2). The current density at the Fe@NG-750 electrode increases with raising rotating speeds due to the improved mass transport at the electrode surface (Fig. S6) [47]. The corresponding Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots show near linear relationship and good parallelity, indicating first-order reaction kinetics toward the concentration of dissolved oxygen. The calculated electron-transfer number (n) is close to 4 from the K-L plots at different rotating speeds (Fig. S7), suggesting the Fe@NG-750 catalyst primarily follows a four-electron reduction path [39]. In addition, Fe@NG-750 shows higher double-layer capacitance (Cdl) (19.2 mF cm−2) and ECSA (480 cm2) than Fe@G-750, which may be due to the higher specific surface area of Fe@NG-750 (Figs. S8 and S9). The effect of annealing temperature on the ORR performance of Fe@NG was investigated. All the Fe@NG-T samples show well-defined cathodic peaks in the O2-saturated electrolyte, whereas the reduction peaks disappear in the Ar-saturated electrolyte (Fig. 3c). Fe@NG-450 gives an ORR onset potential (at 0.1 mA·cm−2) of 0.92 V, a half-wave potential of 0.82 V versus RHE. The ORR performance of Fe@NG-T is improved by increasing the annealing temperature and the best catalytic performance can be obtained when it was annealed at 750 °C. The half-wave potential of Fe@NG-550, Fe@NG-650, Fe@NG-750, and Fe@NG-850 is located at 0.85 V, 0.89 V, 0.90 V, and 0.90 V, respectively (Fig. 3d). The long-term durability of Fe@NG-750 and commercial Pt/C were measured in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. As demonstrated in Fig. 3e, the relative ORR current of 98.4% is remained for the Fe@NG-750 catalyst after continuous reaction for 25,000 s, much higher than that (80.5%) for Pt/C, indicating superior durability of Fe@NG-750. Furthermore, the methanol crossover effect was investigated over Fe@NG-750 and commercial Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 3f). After the addition of methanol, Pt/C catalyst shows a sharp drop in the relative current density, while almost no significant change is observed for the Fe@NG-750 electrode, revealing good methanol-tolerant property of Fe@NG-750. The electrochemical ORR activities of Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were further estimated in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. As displayed in Fig. 4 a, a characteristic oxygen reduction peak can be observed in O2-saturated H2SO4 electrolyte at 0.38 and 0.68 V vs RHE for Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750, respectively, but not in the N2-saturated one. Fe@NG-750 exhibits a half-wave potential of 0.72 V (Fig. 4b), which is more positive than G (0.19 V), NG (0.33 V), and Fe@G-750 (0.37 V), but slightly negative than Pt/C (0.76 V). The Fe@NG annealed at different temperatures also show ORR activity in acidic media. As shown in Fig. 4c, an obvious oxygen reduction peak can be observed in O2-saturated H2SO4 electrolyte for all Fe@NG-T samples. Among the Fe@NG-T samples, Fe@NG-750 exhibits better ORR performance with more positive Eonset of 0.83 V, half-wave potential (E1/2) of 0.72 V vs RHE and higher diffusion limited current density (J d) of 5.7 mA cm−2 than the other four catalysts (Fe@NG-450: Eonset = 0.7 V, E1/2 = 0.43 V, J d = 5.4 mA cm−2; Fe@NG-550: Eonset = 0.79 V, E1/2 = 0.63 V, J d = 5.5 mA cm−2; Fe@NG-650: Eonset = 0.8 V, E1/2 = 0.65 V, J d = 5.6 mA cm−2; Fe@NG-850: Eonset = 0.83 V, E1/2 = 0.72 V, J d = 5.4 mA cm−2) (Fig. 4d). The Tafel slope for the Fe@NG-750 is 47.2 mV·dec−1, which is lower than that for Fe@NG-450 (140.2 mV·dec−1), Fe@NG-550 (87.7 mV·dec−1), Fe@NG-650 (81.3 mV·dec−1), and Fe@NG-850 (48.0 mV·dec−1) (Fig. 4e). The small Tafel slope for the Fe@NG-750 reflects that the rate-determining step should be protonation of O2 − on the Fe-N sites [48]. Fe@NG-750 shows better ORR stability than Pt/C in acidic medium. As shown in Fig. 4f, the retention of ORR current for Fe@NG-750 is over 91% at 0.6 V vs RHE after continuous operation for 14 h, while the retention of ORR current for Pt/C is only 61.3% under the similar conditions. The electrochemical OER activities of Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were first evaluated in 1.0 M KOH. As displayed in Fig. 5 a, the Fe@G-750 exhibits an activity remarkably higher than that of G and NG, with an overpotential of 428 mV at 10 mA cm−2. For the Fe/N-codoped sample Fe@NG-750, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 is measured to be only 194 mV, which is even far lower than that obtained on the present state of the art catalyst IrO2 (∼270 mV), and lower than those achieved on the glassy carbon electrode reported to date (Table 1 ). In addition, the Fe@NG-750 catalyst exhibits comparable Tafel slope (63 mV dec−1) to that of the IrO2 catalyst (57 mV dec−1), and much lower Tafel slope than that of G (157 mV dec−1), NG (143 mV dec−1), and Fe@G-750 (142 mV dec−1) (Fig. 5b), indicating excellent OER kinetics of Fe@NG-750. Moreover, the Tafel slope of Fe@NG-750 is close to 60 mV·dec−1, which can be ascribed to a rate-determining step following the first electron transfer [34]. In addition, Fe@NG-750 demonstrates better electrochemical OER stability than IrO2 in alkaline electrolyte (Fig. S10). The electrochemical stability of Fe@NG-750 can be improved by in-situ supporting it on graphite plate (Fig. S11). The structure and composition of Fe@NG-750 after OER stability test were analysed by XPS. As shown in Fig. S12, the relative surface content of CN bonds almost keeps constant before and after OER. However, the relative surface content of Fe-N bonds in the N-containing species decreases significantly from 16.1 mol.% before OER to 12.8 mol.% after OER. The reduced Fe-N bonds might lead to the decreased Fe-N-C active sites, thus lowering the OER activity. In addition, we have calculated the formation energy of the FeN4 center by using the formula: Δ E f = E FeN 4 -G - E N 4 -G - E Fe ,bcc . The calculated Δ E f is −2.1 eV. Compared to MnN4-G catalyst as reported in our previous work [49], the formation energy of FeN4 is 0.5 eV higher than that of MnN4. In the previous Mn-NG work, we have demonstrated that MnN4-G catalyst is stable during the prolonged stability test for OER. FeN4-G catalyst is obviously less stable due to the higher formation energy. Moreover, by DFT calculations, Liao et al found that water attack on the nitrogen ligand has a low barrier of only 45.6 kJ·mol−1, which leads to the opening of the macrocyclic Fe–TAMLs complexes and thus catalyst degradation [50]. It should be noted that the annealing temperature in ammonia atmosphere might influence the coordination conditions of iron and thus leads to the difference in the OER activity of Fe@NG (Fig. S13). The results show that the optimized annealing temperature for Fe@NG should be 750 °C, followed by 850 °C, and then 650 °C. When the annealing temperature is below 550 °C, poor OER performance is typically observed. It has been reported that the annealing temperature has significant influence on the N-doping level of the Mn/Fe/Co/Ni- and N-codoped graphene, and the optimal annealing temperature should be around 750 °C to form M−N4 active sites [29,49,57]. In addition, the N-coordination to the metal atoms can be precisely controlled by adjusting the annealing temperature. For example, the dominant active center for Co/N-codoped porous carbon materials obtained at 800 °C and 900 °C is Co-N4 and Co-N2, respectively [58]. The electrochemical OER activities of Fe@G-750 and Fe@NG-750 were further evaluated in 0.1 M KOH. As shown in Fig. 5c, to reach j = 10 mA cm−2, the Fe@NG-750 requires only 275 mV overpotential, which is 59 mV smaller than that of IrO2, and 289 mV lower than that of Fe@G-750, again demonstrating the superior OER performance of Fe@NG-750. Moreover, the Tafel slope of Fe@NG-750 is only 67 mV dec−1, close to that of IrO2 (62 mV dec−1), and far lower than that of G, NG, and Fe@G-750 (Fig. 5d). It is worth noting that the Tafel slope of Fe@NG-750 in 0.1 M KOH is similar to that in 1.0 M KOH, demonstrating the same rate-determining step during OER. The application potential of the Fe@NG-750 as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst is investigated, and the overall oxygen electrode activity is assessed by the difference of OER and ORR metrics (ΔE = Ej=10 − E1/2). Fe@NG-750 shows a ΔE of 0.605 V, far lower than that of Pt/C (0.94 V) [7], RuO2 (1.0 V) [7], Fe@G-750 (1.044 V), and most of the bifunctional electrocatalysts reported so far (Table S2). To gain insights into reaction mechanism of Fe@NG-750, the ORR and OER activities of FeN3-G and FeN4-G were examined by DFT calculations, since the Fe-N3 and Fe-N4 species might be the potential active sites in most atomically dispersed Fe-N-C materials [27,59]. A four-step reaction mechanism for ORR and OER on the FeN4-G active site has been proposed as shown in Fig. 6 . For ORR, one oxygen molecule is first absorbed on the FeN4-site, which combines with one proton and one electron to form a Fe-OOH intermediate. Then, it further combines with one proton and one electron to dissociate and form FeO species along with releasing one water molecule. Afterwards, the FeO species is further reduced to form Fe-OH intermediate. Finally, the reduction of FeOH and liberation of H2O complete the catalytic cycle. For OER, the reaction mechanism reverses the process of ORR. The theoretical overpotentials of the ORR and OER on FeN4-G are predicted to be 0.91 V and 0.38 V, respectively. The potential determining step for the ORR is the OOH* formation due to the lack of enough stabilization on the FeN4 site. Comparatively, the ORR overpotential of FeN4-G is higher than that of Pt (1 1 1) surface (0.53 V) in agreement with the acidic ORR results (Fig. 7 ), but much lower than that of FeN2C2-G (1.0 V), FeN3-G (1.73 V), FeN5-G (1.54 V) and FeO3-G (1.78 V) (FeN2C2-G, FeN3-G, FeN4-G, and FeN5-G: possible active sites in Fe@NG-750; FeO3-G: a possible active site in the Fe@G-750) (Fig. S14). It is noted that the FeN2C2-G site is not stable against oxidation, which can be oxidized to FeN2O2-G site. The ORR activity active site on the FeN5-G site is low because of weak interaction with the oxygenated species, while the ORR activity on FeO3-G is also very low due to strong adsorption of the oxygenated species. The overpotential of the OER on FeN4-G is also determined by the formation of OOH*. The water oxidation activity of FeN4-G is higher than those of the FeOOH (0 1 0) surface (a possible active site in the Fe@G-750), FeN3-G, and the IrO2 (1 1 0) surface as shown in Fig. 7. It demonstrates that the change in the coordination environment (from N3 to N4) of the Fe site leads to dramatic decrease in overpotential due to FeN3-G strongly binding the OH* intermediate. These comparisons give strong support to the vital responsibility and necessity of the mononuclear Fe site coupled to four N coordination environments for the superior activity of FeN4-G. 3 Conclusions We developed a simple and effective approach to prepare an atomically dispersed Fe-based electrocatalyst with relatively high content of Fe (up to 1.5 wt%) for ORR and OER with high activity and durability. A one-pot thermal treatment of Fe3+/GO precursor under ammonia atmosphere leads to the formation of atomic Fe- and N-codoped graphene. The N coordination influences the electronic structure of Fe and thus modifies the physicochemical property of the Fe site. Experimental results in combination with DFT calculations reveal that FeN4-moiety embedded into the graphene matrix should be the active site for both ORR and OER. This work provides a facile strategy for the synthesis of high content atomic Fe-based bifunctional electrocatalysts for energy conversion and storage devices. 4 Notes The authors declare no competing financial interest. coredata.dc:description: Development of high-efficiency atomic transition metal catalysts for oxygen electrode reactions is attractive for regenerative energy conversion and storage technologies. Here we report a facile approach to fabricate an atomic iron- and nitrogen-codoped graphene catalyst with high content of iron (up to 1.5 wt%). The atomic iron-based catalyst on glassy carbon electrodes displays low overpotential (194 mV and 275 mV) reported at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH and 0.1 M KOH solutions for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), respectively. In addition, the atomic iron-based composite electrocatalyst exhibits a high half-wave potential of 0.90 V vs. RHE for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in 0.1 M KOH, and a combined ORR and OER potential gap of 0.605 V. Structural characterization and theoretical calculations demonstrate that the efficient active sites for OER and ORR should be FeN4-moiety embedded into the graphene, on which the overpotential-determining step is the OO coupling step.
coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional atomic iron-based catalyst for oxygen electrode reactions
